dt: {bc}the manner in which one behaves or comports oneself {bc}the manner in which one bears {dx_def}see {dxt|bear:2||2f}{/dx_def} oneself

{bc}an object, surface, or point that supports
{bc}a machine part in which another part (such as a journal or pin) turns or slides
{bc}a figure borne on a heraldic field {dx_def}see {dxt|field:1||3c}{/dx_def}
{bc}the situation or horizontal direction of one point with respect to another or to the compass
{bc}comprehension of one's position, environment, or situation

dt.t: The ship lost its {wi}bearings{/wi} in the fog.
facts that have a direct {wi}bearing{/wi} on the question
They assured us that their personal feelings had no {wi}bearing{/wi} on their decision.

dt: {bc}the part of a structural member that rests on its supports

dt.t: a beam with 4 inches of {wi}bearing{/wi} upon the wall

pt: {sc}bearing{/sc} {sc}deportment{/sc} {sc}demeanor{/sc} {sc}mien{/sc} {sc}manner{/sc} {sc}carriage{/sc} mean the outward manifestation of personality or attitude. {sc}bearing{/sc} is the most general of these words but now usually implies characteristic posture.
{sc}deportment{/sc} suggests actions or behavior as formed by breeding or training.
{sc}demeanor{/sc} suggests one's attitude toward others as expressed in outward behavior.
{sc}mien{/sc} is a literary term referring both to bearing and demeanor.
{sc}manner{/sc} implies characteristic or customary way of moving and gesturing and addressing others.

pt.t: the imperious {it}manner{/it} of a man used to giving orders

pt: {sc}carriage{/sc} applies chiefly to habitual posture in standing or walking.

pt.t: the kind of {it}carriage{/it} learned at boarding school

shortdef: the manner in which one behaves or comports oneself : the manner in which one bears oneself
the act, power, or time of bringing forth offspring or fruit

dt: {bc}to accept or allow oneself to be subjected to especially without giving way
{bc}to hold above, on top, or aloft
{bc}to move while holding up and supporting (something)
{bc}to have as a feature or characteristic
{bc}to hold in the mind or emotions
{bc}to go or incline in an indicated direction
{bc}to extend in a direction indicated or implied
{bc}to come to satisfying fruition, production, or development {bc}to produce a desired result or reward
{bc}to think of (something) especially as a warning {bc}{sx|remember||}

pt: {sc}bear{/sc} {sc}suffer{/sc} {sc}endure{/sc} {sc}abide{/sc} {sc}tolerate{/sc} {sc}stand{/sc} mean to put up with something trying or painful. {sc}bear{/sc} usually implies the power to sustain without flinching or breaking.
{sc}suffer{/sc} often suggests acceptance or passivity rather than courage or patience in bearing.
{sc}endure{/sc} implies continuing firm or resolute through trials and difficulties.
{sc}abide{/sc} suggests acceptance without resistance or protest.
{sc}tolerate{/sc} suggests overcoming or successfully controlling an impulse to resist, avoid, or resent something injurious or distasteful.
{sc}stand{/sc} emphasizes even more strongly the ability to bear without discomposure or flinching.

quotes.t: A stone slab {qword}bearing{/qword} 3,000-year-old writing previously unknown to scholars has been found in the Mexican state of Veracruz, and archaeologists say it is an example of the oldest script ever discovered in the Western Hemisphere.

Large public buildings often {qword}bear{/qword} only a loose resemblance to what was originally in the minds of the architects who designed them. Things get cut back to save money; somebody has second thoughts about the way part of the building will function; it takes so long to get public approval that the original idea starts to seem dated …
The most famous work of Louis Pasteur (1822-1895), of course, was purifying milk with the process that now {qword}bears{/qword} his name.

The sight of Niña already there, snugged down as if she had been at home a month, finished Martín Alonso Pinzón. Older than Columbus, ill from the hardships of the voyage, mortified by his snub from the Sovereigns, he could {qword}bear{/qword} no more.

In so-called parking schemes, securities aren't carried on the books of the true owner but are temporarily sold to someone else with the understanding that the seller will continue to {qword}bear{/qword} any risk of loss and reap any profits.

As a science fiction buff, many years ago, I remember being particularly fascinated by tales of genetic surgery. Imagine the surgeon … peering through the electron microscope, repairing the sickle-cell gene and returning the ovum to its mother, who would then {qword}bear{/qword} a normal child.

et: Middle English {it}beren{/it} to carry, bring forth, from Old English {it}beran{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}beran{/it} to carry, Latin {it}ferre{/it}, Greek {it}pherein{/it}
shortdef: to accept or allow oneself to be subjected to especially without giving way
to call for as suitable or essential

shortdef: a bearing in which the journal rotates in peripheral contact with a number of rollers usually contained in a cage

dt: {bc}the space provided at each side of a typeset letter to prevent its touching adjoining letters

shortdef: the space provided at each side of a typeset letter to prevent its touching adjoining letters

dt: {bc}the act or state of supporting or withstanding the weight of something (such as a building or the body)

dt.t: The involved bones are deformed by the stress of {wi}weight-bearing{/wi} or even by the normal pull of attached muscles.
If Iguanodon walked on all fours, then the hand and wrist ought to be adapted for {wi}weight-bearing{/wi}.
For bones, {wi}weight-bearing{/wi} activities like walking, running and weight lifting are especially important.

An athlete who suffers an injury to a major {wi}weight-bearing{/wi} joint, such as the hip or knee, is five to seven times more likely to develop degenerative arthritis than an average member of the population.
Engineers typically use strain gauges to measure the stresses on automobile parts, chains, bridges and other {wi}weight-bearing{/wi} objects.

… structural steel, elevators and telephones were emancipating urban architecture from limits imposed by the {wi}weight-bearing{/wi} capacity of stone walls and the stair-climbing endurance of people.

shortdef: the act or state of supporting or withstanding the weight of something (such as a building or the body) —usually used before another noun

dt: {bc}too painful, unpleasant, etc., to be accepted or endured

shortdef: too painful, unpleasant, etc., to be accepted or endured

dt.t: Personal feelings {it}had no bearing on{/it} our decision.

shortdef: to affect or influence a decision —usually used in negative statements

dt: {bc}to exert full strength and concentrated attention

shortdef: to exert full strength and concentrated attention
